intro: Acaena macrostemon subsp. longiaristata, commonly known as the long-stalked New Zealand bramble, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its prickly stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences. Its fruit is a spherical, dry achene enclosed in a persistent, woody bract. This subspecies is adapted to a variety of habitats, including coastal and forest margins, and is often found in the lower North Island of New Zealand.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena macrostemon subsp. longiaristata is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This subspecies thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It is commonly associated with disturbed soils and can often be found along roadsides and in agricultural areas. The plant is part of the bramble family and is known for its small, spiny fruits.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena macrostemon subsp. longiaristata was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the broader introduction of the Acaena genus for ornamental purposes. This subspecies is commonly found in the North Island, particularly in coastal and lowland areas. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it adaptable to various environments. However, it is considered a potential weed in some regions due to its aggressive growth habit.
